did.abstract: Heavily edited, much of this material was used in his lectures on physiology. The section "Of pleasure: Lect: 20th" (ff. 473-477), corresponds word-for-word with some parts of "Two Lectures upon the Pleasures of the Senses and of the Mind," at the end of his "Sixteen Introductory Lectures" (Philadelphia, 1811).

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Received from College of Physicians of Philadelphia and accessioned, 1959 (1959 1168mf).

odd.head: General note
odd.p: This item was published in Earl T. Carlson, Jeffrey L. Wollock, and Patricia S. Noel, eds., "Benjamin Rush's Lectures on the Mind," American Philosophical Society Memoirs, v.144 (1981).

bioghist.head: Biographical/Historical note
bioghist.p: Benjamin Rush was a physician, patriot, and humanitarian. He graduated from the College of New Jersey (Princeton), 1760, and from the University of Edinburgh, 1768. He was a member of the staff at the Pennsylvania Hospital and was a professor at the University of Pennsylvania.
